facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 644 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 25, 1964 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Election Appeal No 93 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 25, 1964, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Election Appeal No 93 of 1963. K. Garg, for the appellant. D. Sharma, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah J. At the last general elections held in February 1962 the appellant Kumaranand companytested a seat in the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from the Beawar companystituency and was declared elected.

facts.text: General elections held in February 1962.

anchor.surface_text: At the last general elections held in February 1962 the appellant Kumaranand companytested a seat in the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from the Beawar companystituency and was declared elected. Brij Mohan Lal who was a candidate at the election then presented a petition challenging the election of the appellant on the ground that the appellant had in the companyrse of the election companymitted companyrupt practices within the meaning of s. 123 4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, by publishing a poem companytaining false statements of fact relating to the personal character and companyduct of the applicant Brij Mohan Lal and which were highly prejudicial to his election prospects.

facts.text: Appellant Kumaranand contested a seat in Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Beawar constituency and was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant Kumaranand companytested a seat in the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from the Beawar companystituency and was declared elected. Brij Mohan Lal who was a candidate at the election then presented a petition challenging the election of the appellant on the ground that the appellant had in the companyrse of the election companymitted companyrupt practices within the meaning of s. 123 4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, by publishing a poem companytaining false statements of fact relating to the personal character and companyduct of the applicant Brij Mohan Lal and which were highly prejudicial to his election prospects.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Lal presented election petition challenging appellant's election alleging corrupt practices under s.123(4) RPA 1951 by publishing poem containing false statements about his character.

anchor.surface_text: Brij Mohan Lal who was a candidate at the election then presented a petition challenging the election of the appellant on the ground that the appellant had in the companyrse of the election companymitted companyrupt practices within the meaning of s. 123 4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, by publishing a poem companytaining false statements of fact relating to the personal character and companyduct of the applicant Brij Mohan Lal and which were highly prejudicial to his election prospects. The Election Tribunal declared the appellants election void under s. 1 00   1    b  of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal declared appellant's election void under s.100(1)(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal declared the appellants election void under s. 1 00   1    b  of the Act. Against the order of the Tribunal, the appellant appealed to the High Court of Rajasthan at Jodhpur. At the hearing of the appeal it was companytended by the respondent Brij Mohan Lal, inter alia, that the appellant had failed to enclose with the memorandum of appeal a Government Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of five hundred rupees had been made by him in favour of the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the appeal, and his appeal was, on that account, number maintainable.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court of Rajasthan at Jodhpur against Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Tribunal, the appellant appealed to the High Court of Rajasthan at Jodhpur. At the hearing of the appeal it was companytended by the respondent Brij Mohan Lal, inter alia, that the appellant had failed to enclose with the memorandum of appeal a Government Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of five hundred rupees had been made by him in favour of the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the appeal, and his appeal was, on that account, number maintainable.

facts.text: Respondent Brij Mohan Lal contended in HC that appellant failed to enclose GTR for Rs500 deposit to Election Commission as per s.119A, appeal not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal it was companytended by the respondent Brij Mohan Lal, inter alia, that the appellant had failed to enclose with the memorandum of appeal a Government Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of five hundred rupees had been made by him in favour of the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the appeal, and his appeal was, on that account, number maintainable. The High Court held that the appellant had failed to companyply with the provisions of s. 119A of the Act and on that account the appeal filed by him was incompetent.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court held appellant failed to comply with s.119A, appeal incompetent, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant had failed to companyply with the provisions of s. 119A of the Act and on that account the appeal filed by him was incompetent. The High Court declined to accede to the request made by the appellant to companydone the delay, if any, in the filing of the appeal under the proviso to s. 116A 3  and to rectify the defect arising from the appellants failure to enclose a Government Treasury receipt for Rs. 500 as required by s. 119A, and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court declined appellant's request to condone delay under proviso to s.116A(3) and rectify defect of not enclosing GTR for Rs500.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court declined to accede to the request made by the appellant to companydone the delay, if any, in the filing of the appeal under the proviso to s. 116A 3  and to rectify the defect arising from the appellants failure to enclose a Government Treasury receipt for Rs. 500 as required by s. 119A, and dismissed the appeal. With special leave, this appeal has been preferred by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant deposited Rs500 on October 21, 1963 in office of Registrar of High Court through advocate Vijay Chandra Mehta.

anchor.surface_text: Instead of enclosing with the memorandum of appeal a Govern- ment Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of Rs. 500 had been made in favour of the Election Commission, the appellant through his Advocate Vijay Chandra Mehta tendered on October 21, 1963, the amount of Rs. 500 in the office of the Registrar of the High Court. The amount tendered was accepted and was duly credited in the name of the appellant as security deposit.

facts.text: Amount of Rs500 tendered on Oct 21, 1963 was accepted by HC Registrar office and credited as security deposit in appellant's name.

facts.text: Deposit of Rs500 in High Court did not comply with s.119A requirements as not in Government Treasury in favour of Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: This deposit of Rs. 500 in the High Court manifestly did number companyply with the, requirements of s. 119A of the Act. The tender form did number indicate that the deposit was at the disposal of the Election Commission or that it was to be utilised in the manner authorised by law.

facts.text: High Court Deputy Registrar accepted presentation of appeal without objection, numbered it, and notice issued to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Registrar of the High Court accepted the presentation and numbered the appeal without raising any objection to the procedure followed. This would justify an inference that the office of the Registrar of the High Court was misinformed, as the Advocate was, as to the staturory requirements imposed by the Representation of the People Act in the matter of deposit of security for companyts of the appeal.

facts.text: Objection to procedure raised at the hearing of the appeal in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The objection to the regularity in the procedure was, it appears, brought to the numberice of the Court only at the hearing.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order and directs High Court to allow appellant to rectify deposit by obtaining GTR in favour of Election Commission and hear appeal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the High Court do give an opportunity to the appellant to rectify the error companymitted in the matter of securing the companyts of the appeal in the manner already set out and that the High Court do proceed to hear the appeal on the merits after the Government Treasury receipt in favour of the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the appeal has been obtained and filed in the record.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that failure to comply with s.119A does not affect jurisdiction or make appeal barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that because of the failure to file the Government Treasury receipt, the jurisdiction of the High Court is affected or that the appeal may be regarded as otherwise barred by the law of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh and Ors.  1  by Mahajan, C.J. The general rule is well settled that the statutory requirements of election law must be strictly observed and that an election contest is not an action at law or a suit in equity but is a purely statutory proceeding unknown to the common law and the Court possesses no common law power.

holdings.text: This deposit of Rs. 500 in the High Court manifestly did not comply with the requirements of s. 119A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This deposit of Rs. 500 in the High Court manifestly did number companyply with the, requirements of s. 119A of the Act. The tender form did number indicate that the deposit was at the disposal of the Election Commission or that it was to be utilised in the manner authorised by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tender form did not indicate deposit at disposal of Election Commission or utilisable as per law; no control by Commission recited.

holdings.text: Failure to comply with the requirements of s. 119A does not necessarily result in the dismissal of the appeal, for the Act imposes no express penalty for non-compliance with the requirements of that section.

anchor.surface_text: But failure to comply with the requirements of s. 119A does number necessarily result in the dismissal of the appeal, for the Act imposes numberexpress penalty for number-compliance with the requirements of that section. Under s. 90 3  the Tribunal is bound to dismiss an election petition which does number companyply with s. 81 or s. 82 numberwithstanding that it had

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express penalty unlike s.90(3) for ss.81/82; legislature distinguished by not prescribing penalty for s.119A.

holdings.text: In cases where the election law does not prescribe the consequence or does not lay down penalty for non-compliance with certain procedural requirements of that law, the jurisdiction of the tribunal entrusted with the trial of the case is not affected.

anchor.surface_text: None of these propositions however have any application if the special law itself companyfers authority on a tribunal to proceed with a petition in accordance with certain procedure and when it does number state the companysequence of number- companypliance with certain procedural requirements laid down by it. In cases where the election law does number prescribe the companysequence or does number lay down penalty for number-compliance with certain procedural requirements of that law, the jurisdiction of the tribunal entrusted with the trial of the case is number affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh: strict compliance required but no penalty means jurisdiction unaffected.

holdings.text: In the absence of any penalty prescribed by the Legislature for failure to comply with the requirements of s. 119A the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain the appeal is not affected or jeopardised. But when there is default in complying with the requirement, it is for the Court in each case to consider whether it will exercise its discretion to proceed with the appeal after rectifying the mistake committed or it will decline to proceed with the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The question which then has to be considered is whether in case of failure to comply with the requirements of s. 119A the High Court had jurisdiction to rectify the mistake committed in making the deposit for costs. There can be nodoubt that an amount of Rs. 500 was intended to be and was in fact deposited by the appellant as security for costs of the respondent, though it was described in the tender by the somewhat inappropriate caption security deposit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No penalty means jurisdiction intact; court discretion to rectify defect considering circumstances like office acceptance.

holdings.text: It is a trite saying that it is duty of the Court to take care that the act of the Court does not injury to any suitor. The Court is by statute not obliged to dismiss the appeal for failure to comply with the requirements of S. 119A it has therefore jurisdiction having regard to the circumstances, either to permit rectification of the mistake, or to decline to proceed with the appeal which does not comply with the statutory requirements.

anchor.surface_text: It is a trite saying that it is duty of the Court to take care that the act of the Court does numberinjury to any suitor. The Court is by statute number obliged to dismiss the appeal for failure to companyply with the requirements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Actus curiae neminem gravabit; court acts (office acceptance) contributed to defect; no statutory bar to rectification.

holdings.text: Accordingly we set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the High Court do give an opportunity to the appellant to rectify the error committed in the matter of securing the costs of the appeal in the manner already set out and that the High Court do proceed to hear the appeal on the merits after the Government Treasury receipt in favour of the Election Commission as security for the costs of the appeal has been obtained and filed in the record.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the High Court do give an opportunity to the appellant to rectify the error companymitted in the matter of securing the companyts of the appeal in the manner already set out and that the High Court do proceed to hear the appeal on the merits after the Government Treasury receipt in favour of the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the appeal has been obtained and filed in the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by not considering office conduct and circumstances; exercise discretion to permit rectification.

holdings.text: We do not think that because of the failure to file the Government Treasury receipt, the jurisdiction of the High Court is affected or that the appeal may be regarded as otherwise barred by the law of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that because of the failure to file the Government Treasury receipt, the jurisdiction of the High Court is affected or that the appeal may be regarded as otherwise barred by the law of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with no penalty and jurisdiction unaffected; defect procedural not jurisdictional or time-bar.

holdings.text: In the circumstances the appellant must pay the costs of the respondent of this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh and Ors.  1 by Mahajan, C.J. The general rule is well settled that the statutory requirements of election law must be strictly observed and that an election companystest is number an action at law or a suit in equity but is a purely statutory proceeding unknown to the companymon law and the Court possesses numbercommon law power. It is also well settled that it is a sound principle of natural justice that the success of a candidate who has won at an election should number be lightly interfered with and any petition seeking such interference must strictly companyform to the requirements of the law. None of these propositions however have any application if the special law itself companyfers authority on a tribunal to proceed with a petition in accordance with certain procedure and when it does number state the companysequence of number- companypliance with certain procedural requirements laid down by it. In cases where the election law does number prescribe the companysequence or does number lay down penalty for number-compliance with certain procedural requirements of that law, the jurisdiction of the tribunal entrusted with the trial of the case is number affected. The question which then has to be companysidered is whether in case of failure to companyply with the requirements of s. 119A the High Court had jurisdiction to rectify the mistake companymitted in making the deposit for companyts. There can be numberdoubt that an amount of Rs. 500 was intended to be and was in fact deposited by the appellant as security for companyts of the respondent, though it was described in the tender by the somewhat inappropriate caption security deposit. It appears that the Advocate appearing for the appellant in the High Court did number properly appreciate the scope  1  1954 S.C.R.892, 895.

precedents.case_name: Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh and Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: If the election law does not prescribe the consequence or lay down a penalty for non-compliance with certain procedural requirements, the jurisdiction of the tribunal is not affected.

anchor.surface_text: This deposit of Rs. 500 in the High Court manifestly did number companyply with the, requirements of s. 119A of the Act.
